column2: ENGLISH
column3: FRENCH
column4: GERMAN
column6: SPANISH

column2: The Rain is continuing in [Root.GetName] and we haven't seen a blue sky for weeks. We need sufficient rain for our fields, but exessive rain will cause a bad crop in comming autumn.
May [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName] help us!
The weather in [Root.GetName] is extremely cold in this year. A cool summer is welcome, however poor people are dying at cold and peasants begin to worry about their crops in autumn.
[Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName], please help us!
Because of bad weathers or deamon's work, the crops in [Root.GetName] is terrible in this year. We have to prepare the coming food shortage.
Let's hope that we can survive this winter.

The bad crops brought a serious famine in [Root.GetName]! There is nothing to eat and the peasants sell their family as slave. They might be still happier than the people who have been dead at hungry.
Buy foods and help poor peasants and citizens!
Let them eat cake!
Thanks to the protection of [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName], we had good crops in [Root.GetName]. We can hold a great harvest feast in this year!
We won't have to worry about the winter!
I expressed my wishes and desires for a coronation in Rome to his Holiness the Pope. Hopefully he will accept my request so that I can begin inviting my lords to attend the coronation ceremony.
He better accept!

To The most Reverend and Blessed Apostolic Pope,

I would like to ask you for your blessing in my rule as Emperor by officially holding a coronation ceremony in my honour.

Your most devoted subject,
[From.GetTitledName]
Send a reply that I would support his coronation.
He asks me to crown him? Who does he think he is!

To the most devout and serene [Root.GetTitledFirstName],
In the name of the Lord, I, [From.GetTitledName], would like to offer you my blessing to allow your coronation in Rome, as Most Pious [Root.GetTitledFirstName], under my guidance.
 Yours, 
[From.GetBestName]
Excellent, send out the a message to invite all my lords

To his Majesty [Root.GetTitledFirstName],
In the name of the Lord, I, [From.GetTitledName], would like to inform you that I deem you are not yet worthy and just enough as a ruler to be offered my blessings to become crowned as Most Pious [Root.GetTitledFirstName]. The Lord surely has much faith in you as you have in him, but remember that the honour of receiving His blessing does not come easy and is only for the purest of souls.
Signed,
[From.GetTitledName]
Why can't he ever just say: 'No'!

To Noble [Root.GetTitledFirstName],
You should be happy to know that, I, [From.GetTitledName], will hold a coronation ceremony in Rome in my honour with the blessing of his Holiness the Pope. You received the honour to be invited to attend the ceremony, which will be held soon in Rome. I await your postive reply.

Your most Holy Lord and Liege,
[From.GetTitledName]
I will write to him that I will attend
What arrogance! I will inform him about his attitude
[From.GetTitledName] is sorry to inform you that he will not be able to attend the coronation ceremony in Rome as he has more important issues to attend to.
I have no words for such dishonour
Most Pious [Root.GetTitledFirstName]
The Papal Coronation

In the name of Christ, I, [Root.GetTitledFirstName], promise, pledge and guarantee in the sight of God and the blessed Apostle Peter that I will be the protector and defender of this holy Roman Church in all ways useful to her, however many, in so far as I am supported by divine assistance according to my knowledge and ability.\n\nToday [Root.GetTitledFirstName] was crowned by his Holiness the Pope and formally received the title of 'Most Pious [Root.GetTitledFirstName]' and the Imperial Regalia with the blessing of the Pope.
Today I was crowned by his Holiness the Pope and formally received the title of 'Most Pious [Root.GetTitledFirstName]' and the Imperial Regalia with the blessing of the Pope.
This will strengthen my rule significantly

Today [From.GetTitledFirstName] was crowned by his Holiness the Pope and formally received the title of 'Most Pious [From.GetTitledFirstName]' and the Imperial Regalia with the blessing of the Pope. The ceremony was magnificent.
Long live [From.GetTitledFirstName]!

[From.GetTitledFirstName] has been crowned and received the Imperial Regalia by his holiness the Pope in the St. Basilica in Rome. The divine blessings conveyed by his Holiness the Pope confirm the right of rule over all Imperial lands governed by [From.GetTitledFirstName] and his appointed vassals.
OK
[From.GetTitledFirstName] has decided to offer you the throne when he chose to abdicate.
Grand!
Your heir has accepted the throne!
Pillaging through the ruins of a temple in Tyrus I stumbled across the pieces of a very old cross...
I must have found a piece of the Holy cross!
Prying open a tomb in Tiberias that had been sealed for centuries, I found a very old remains of an Holy man...
Could it be... One of the Apostles!
Safed is finally ours after a horrific siege. Entering the city we rode in the blood of the infidels up to the knees of our horses.
Let's sack the castle!
You hear of the chance of participating in a nearby Duchy's swordsmanship tournament, but since your prowess with a sword is well known you'll have to go under a disguise..
I shall go in disguise and show them my great skills!
I have a dignity.
The Pope is really mad at you because your stature is starting to obscure his...
He is a great man of the Church.
I'm ten times as holy as thy are!
I think this gold will make his eyes shine..
I can't even spell my last name right, and all my fellow vassals and peers are always making fun of my ignorance..
I shall get educated at once!
Ignorance is a virtue...
In the midst of battle I find myself with the chance of trying a swift and brilliant move, who could turn the sort of the clash in our favour.
It's too risky!
Audaces fortuna iuvat.
My chancellor and fellow peers have just suggested that I organize a fair in the name of knowledge and philosophy!
I hate suggestions.
This is a grand idea!
Make it golden!
I came up with a brilliant plan to kidnap the daughter of the richest merchant of the realm. Now all that's left is to hire some thugs for the monkey business part.
I was only fantasizing.
I'll pay them half the ransom.
I'll promise them half the ransom and have them  killed by my men before they can get their hands on the gold.
After years and years of work I came up with a master plan that could reform my demesne down to its roots.
Little by little.
There's no time to be wasted here!
Preservation is the most important thing.
Your steward tells you that the local Jewish community is asking for permission to hold celebrations for the next Hanukah in the streets of [Root.Capital.GetName].
I hate those Jews.
Granted!
I'll think about it.
The local Rabbi suggests you issue a treaty to put the Jews of the realm under your protection.
Something wicked this way comes.
I shall sign it right away.
Your stewards tells you of the chance to institute a moneylending bank in the realm.
This is sinful!
A wonderful thought.
I don't think it's the right moment for this.
Your Chancellor suggest you commission a tapestry of your most famous battles and adventures.
It's a waste of money.
It will look most grand in my castle.
Our steward points out a chance to reform our monetary system into a more efficient one.
He's got to be kidding me
Reforms are what we need!
A musician comes knocking at your door, asking for patronage in exchange for a composition on the many tales and deeds of your dynasty.
I sing well enough while I bathe.
If music be the food of love, play on.
I'll give him patronage.
An errant composer petitions you for a place at your court, in exchange for an inside look at the arts of music and the poetry behind it.
I always wanted to be a composer!
I'll ask him to focus on poetry instead.
What is this buzz you call symphony?!
A famous alchemist approaches you with a formula for an elixir that, he claims, will make the person who drinks it extra lucky in every field.
Shut the old fool's mouth!
I'll oversee the experiment.
I shall take part in the experiment.
Breaking news! The Pope has accused me of sorcery because of my latest experiments on a way of turning iron into gold.
I bend my knees in front of Jesus our Lord and Saviour.
He won't laugh when he's six feet under.
Reassure him but keep focusing on the experiment.
Your latest economical reforms have been dreadful for the coffers of the realm.
Blame it on the steward.
I will do everything to fix it.
Let it be.
Leadership Improvement
The recent battle has given me a chance to improve my combat tactic, strategy and leadership. I have become a more proficient commander.
Excellent!
A New Way Of Life?

It was some kind of  revelation: The battlefield in front of me, my men moving towards the enemy. I was sitting on my horse, commanding the troops, and although I have never been a great war leader, we won the battle. When the dust had settled, my men were cheering at me and even my companions praised my talent. Maybe this is my true calling?
The way of the warrior.
I am what I am.
Martial Skill Improvement
The recent battle has given me a chance to improve my combat tactic, strategy and leadership. I have become a more proficient commander.
Excellent!
A revolt has broken out in [Root.GetName]! Angered by my 'oppressive' rule, the peasants have taken arms against me!
How dare they oppose me!

A revolt has broken out in [From.GetName]! Angered by the oppressive rule of [From.County.Holder.GetTitledName], the peasants have taken arms against my vassal. Their indiscriminate destruction will unfortunately hit my holdings as well...
If the count doesn't act, I better...
The peasant army ravageing the province of [Root.GetName] is burning down buildings!
Is there anything they won't destroy?
Bad news, but I am glad it didn't happen to my holdings...
The peasant army ravageing the province of [From.GetName] is burning down my buildings!
I have been attacked by the peasants rebels in [Root.Location.GetName]!
They killed me?!
Damn these rebels!
I am lucky to be alive...
[From.GetTitledName] has been captured and killed by peasant rebels!
How dare they execute a subject of mine!

My liege,
I was ambushed by a mob of peasant rebels and barely got away with my life. The attack has left me maimed and I fear for the life of me and those around me in [From.Location.GetName]. These rebels must be stopped.

Signed,
[From.GetTitledName]
They sure do...

My liege,
Although I escaped with my life, the mob of peasant rebels that attacked me managed to wound me. I fear these attacks will only increase until the revolt in [From.Location.GetName] is put down.
Signed,
[From.GetTitledName]
This peasant rabble must be stopped!
Feeling little loyalty to the far off ruler of [Root.Holder.Liege.PrimaryTitle.GetName], the peasant rebels of [Root.GetName] have defected and sworn allegiance to another ruler!
Tired of their old ruler, the peasant rebels of [Root.GetName] have defected and sworn allegiance to me!
Excellent! Or is it...?

Feeling little loyalty to the far off ruler of [FromFrom.Holder.Liege.PrimaryTitle.GetName], the peasant rebels of [FromFrom.GetName] have defected and sworn allegiance to [From.County.Holder.GetTitledName]!
Damn these peasants!
Outrages!
$PROVINCENAME$ is isolated from the rest of the realm. It is difficult to control
Ok
$PROVINCENAME$ is no longer isolated
Good
Revolting peasants in $PROVINCENAME$ will depose arms if you agree to reduce their taxes
Very well
Don`t listen to the peasant scum!
Revolt suppressed
I arrived to [Root.Location.GetName] and managed to find and arrest revolt leaders. Without them peasants will not dare to oppose my liege any more
They learned their lesson!
Send a letter to my liege
My liege, I managed to find and arrest revolt leaders in [From.Location.GetName]. Without them the peasants will not dare to oppose you any more.
Good news!

For as long as have ruled here we Normans have entrusted the raising of our children to Greek, Maghreb, or Italian nursemaids. Our first words would not be Norman French but something else. As we grew up, we learned to speak a tongue that was neither one nor the other. Now is this time to make this tongue our own so we may all communicate.
Yes, let us be one with our serfs

Around our lands more people are using this Sicilian language and I find this is a perfect means for a Norman overlord to get his multicultural serfs to work properly. We continue to use our own influence to promote this means of communication in the interests of a more efficient realm.
We are indeed wise

Although every civilised man in Christendom knows that French is the true language of communication, this new Sicilian language does have a certain functionality. I have therefore prevailed upon a member of my court to adopt this for everyday administrative use.
A most useful development

I was considering important business when I had an amazing insight. To strengthen my realm I must bring my vassals round to my way of thinking. This involves communication. If I can get them to communicate like me then I will have a much smoother running realm.
Sometimes I even surprise myself
My Liege has persuded me to embrace this notion of Sicilianness that is sweeping the realm.
He made me an offer I couldn't refuse.

For as long as have ruled here we Greeks have entrusted the raising of our children to Norman, Maghreb, or Italian nursemaids. Our first words would not be Byzantine Greek but something else. As we grew up, we learned to speak a tongue that was neither one nor the other. Now is this time to make this tongue our own so we may all communicate.
Yes, let us be one with our serfs

Around our lands more people are using this Sicilian language and I find this is a perfect means for a Greek overlord to get his multicultural serfs to work properly. We continue to use our own influence to promote this means of communication in the interests of a more efficient realm.
We are indeed wise

Although every civilised man in Christendom knows that Greek is the true language of communication, this new Sicilian language does have a certain functionality. I have therefore prevailed upon a member of my court to adopt this for everyday administrative use.
A most useful development

I was considering important business when I had an amazing insight. To strengthen my realm I must bring my vassals round to my way of thinking. This involves communication. If I can get them to communicate like me then I will have a much smoother running realm.
Sometimes I  surprise even myself
My Liege has persuded me to embrace this notion of Sicilianness that is sweeping the realm.
He made me an offer I couldn't refuse.

For as long as have ruled here we Arabs have entrusted the raising of our children to Norman, Greek, or Italian nursemaids. Our first words would not be Maghreb Arabic but something else. As we grew up, we learned to speak a tongue that was neither one nor the other. Now is this time to make this tongue our own so we may all communicate.
Yes, let us be one with our serfs

Around our lands more people are using this Sicilian language and I find this is a perfect means for an Arab overlord to get his multicultural serfs to work properly. We continue to use our own influence to promote this means of communication in the interests of a more efficient realm.
We are indeed wise

Although every civilised man in Christendom knows that Arabic is the true language of communication, this new Sicilian language does have a certain functionality. I have therefore prevailed upon a member of my court to adopt this for everyday administrative use.
A most useful development

I was considering important business when I had an amazing insight. To strengthen my realm I must bring my vassals round to my way of thinking. This involves communication. If I can get them to communicate like me then I will have a much smoother running realm.
Sometimes I even surprise myself
My Liege has persuded me to embrace this notion of Sicilianness that is sweeping the realm.
He made me an offer I couldn't refuse.
Thomas Aquinas
Thomas Aquinas was an Italian Dominican priest of the Roman Catholic Church, and an immensely influential philosopher and theologian in the tradition of scholasticism.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Albertus Magnus
Albertus Magnus was a German Dominican friar and a bishop who achieved fame for his comprehensive knowledge of and advocacy for the peaceful coexistence of science and religion.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
John Peckham

John Peckham wrote a number of works on optics, philosophy, and theology, as well as writing hymns. Numerous manuscripts of his works survive. On his death, his body was buried in Canterbury Cathedral, as he was elected archibishop of Canterbury.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Roger Bacon

Roger Bacon was an English philosopher and Franciscan friar who placed considerable emphasis on the study of nature through empirical methods. He is sometimes credited, mainly starting in the 19th century, as one of the earliest European advocates of the modern scientific method inspired by the works of Aristotle and later pseudo-Aristotelian works, like the works of Egyptian scientist Alhazen.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Thomas Bradwardine

Thomas Bradwardine was an English scholar, scientist, courtier and, very briefly, Archbishop of Canterbury. As a celebrated scholastic philosopher and doctor of theology, he is often called Doctor Profundus.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
William of Ockham

William of Ockham was an English Franciscan friar and scholastic philosopher, who is believed to have been born in Ockham, a small village in Surrey. He is considered to be one of the major figures of medieval thought and was at the centre of the major intellectual and political controversies of the fourteenth century.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Johannes de Sacrobosco

Johannes de Sacrobosco was a scholar, monk, and astronomer (probably English, but possibly Irish or Scottish) who taught at the University of Paris and wrote the authoritative mediaeval astronomy text Tractatus de Sphaera.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Duns Scotus

Duns Scotus was one of the more important theologians and philosophers of the High Middle Ages. He was nicknamed Doctor Subtilis for his penetrating and subtle manner of thought. Scotus has had considerable influence on Roman Catholic thought. The doctrines for which he is best known are the 'univocity of being,' that existence is the most abstract concept we have, applicable to everything that exists, the formal distinction, a way of distinguishing between different aspects of the same thing.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Erasmus Witelo
Erasmus Witelo  was a friar, theologian and scientist: a physicist, natural philosopher, mathematician. He is an important figure in the history of philosophy in Poland.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Jean Buridan

Jean Buridan was a French priest. He developed the concept of impetus, the first step toward the modern concept of inertia, and an important development in the history of medieval science. His name is most familiar through the thought experiment known as Buridan's ass.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Nicole Oresme

Nicole Oresme was a significant philosopher of the later Middle Ages. He wrote influential works on economics, mathematics, physics, astronomy, philosophy, and theology, was Bishop of Lisieux, a translator, a counselor of King Charles V of France, and probably one of the most original thinkers of the 14th century.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Vincent of Beauvais
The Dominican friar Vincent of Beauvais wrote the Speculum Maius, the main encyclopedia that was used in the Middle Ages.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Richard of Wallingford
Richard of Wallingford  was an English mathematician who made major contributions to astronomy/astrology and horology while serving as abbot of St Albans Abbey in Hertfordshire.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Petrarch

Petrarch was an Italian scholar, poet and one of the earliest humanists. Petrarch is often called the 'Father of Humanism'. Petrarch's sonnets were admired and imitated throughout Europe during the Renaissance and became a model for lyrical poetry. He is also known for being the first to develop the concept of the 'Dark Ages'.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Dante

Dante Alighieri was an Italian poet, prose writer, literary theorist, moral philosopher, and political thinker. He is best known for the monumental epic poem La commedia, later named La divina commedia (Divine Comedy), considered the greatest literary work composed in the Italian language and a masterpiece of world literature.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Boccaccio

Giovanni Boccaccio was an Italian author and poet, a friend, student, and correspondent of Petrarch, an important Renaissance humanist and the author of a number of notable works including the Decameron, On Famous Women, and his poetry in the Italian vernacular. Boccaccio is particularly notable for his dialogue, of which it has been said that it surpasses in verisimilitude that of virtually all of his contemporaries, since they were medieval writers and often followed formulaic models for character and plot.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Saint Bonaventure

Giovanni di Fidanza was an Italian medieval scholastic theologian and philosopher. The seventh Minister General of the Order of Friars Minor, he was also a Cardinal Bishop of Albano. He was canonized on 14 April 1482 by Pope Sixtus IV and declared a Doctor of the Church in the year 1588 by Pope Sixtus V.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Moshe ibn Ezra

Moshe ibn Ezrawas a Jewish, Spanish philosopher, linguist, and poet. Ezra is Jewish by religion but is also considered a great influence in the Arabic world in regards to his works. He is considered one of the greatest poets to originate from Spain and was thought of as ahead of his time in terms of theories surrounding the nature of poetry. One of the more revolutionary aspects of Ezra’s poetry that have been debated over is his definition of poetry as metaphor and how it fuses Aristotle’s early ideas.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Benjamin of Tudela

Benjamin of Tudela was a medieval Jewish traveler who visited Europe, Asia, and Africa in the 12th century. His vivid descriptions of western Asia preceded those of Marco Polo by a hundred years. With his broad education and vast knowledge of languages, Benjamin of Tudela is a major figure in medieval geography and Jewish history.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Judah Halevi

Judah Halevi was a Spanish Jewish physician, poet and philosopher. Halevi is considered one of the greatest Hebrew poets, celebrated both for his religious and secular poems, many of which appear in present-day liturgy. His greatest philosophical work was The Kuzari.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
This wench is young and beautiful, and she even looks like she knows a couple of nice tricks! She's gonna make a perfect concubine.
It's good to be the [This.GetTitle]
This lad is young, fine and very handsome indeed! He's gonna make a perfect lover.
It's good to be the [This.GetTitle]
Saint Francis of Assisi

Saint Francis of Assisi was an Italian Catholic friar and preacher. He founded the men's Franciscan Order, the women’s Order of St. Clare, and the lay Third Order of Saint Francis. St. Francis is one of the most venerated religious figures in history.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Marco Polo

Marco Polo was a Venetian merchant traveler from the Venetian Republic whose travels are recorded in Il Milione, a book which did much to introduce Europeans to Central Asia and China. He learned about trading whilst his father and uncle, Niccolò and Maffeo, travelled through Asia and apparently met Kublai Khan.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Niccolò de' Conti

Niccolò de' Conti was an Italian merchant and explorer of the Republic of Venice, born in Chioggia, who traveled to India and Southeast Asia, and possibly to Southern China, during the early 15th century. After the return of the Marco Polo in 1295, there is no record of Italian traders returning from China until the return of Niccolò de' Conti by sea in 1439.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Robert Grosseteste

Robert Grosseteste was an English statesman, scholastic philosopher, theologian, scientist and Bishop of Lincoln. He was born of humble parents at Stradbroke in Suffolk. He might be 'the real founder of the tradition of scientific thought in medieval Oxford, and in some ways, of the modern English intellectual tradition'.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Geoffrey Chaucer

Geoffrey Chaucer known as the Father of English literature, is widely considered the greatest English poet of the Middle Ages and was the first poet to have been buried in Poet's Corner of Westminster Abbey. While he achieved fame during his lifetime as an author, philosopher, alchemist and astronomer, composing a scientific treatise on the astrolabe for his ten year-old son Lewis, Chaucer also maintained an active career in the civil service as a bureaucrat, courtier and diplomat.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Thomas Becket

Thomas Becket  was Archbishop of Canterbury from 1162 until his murder in 1170. He is venerated as a saint and martyr by both the Catholic Church and the Anglican Communion. He engaged in conflict with Henry II of England over the rights and privileges of the Church and was assassinated by followers of the king in Canterbury Cathedral. Soon after his death, he was canonized by Pope Alexander III.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Peter Waldo

Peter Waldo is credited as the founder of the Waldensians, a Christian spiritual movement of the Middle Ages, descendants of which still exist in various regions of southern Europe. Due to lack of reliable documentation there is a great degree of debate over Waldo's role in the Waldensian sect which may have existed before his leadership, while the French historian Thuanus dated his death to the year 1179.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
André de Longjumeau

André de Longjumeau was a 13th century Dominican missionary and diplomat and one of the most active Occidental diplomats in the East in the 13th century. He led two embassies to the Mongols: the first carried letters from Pope Innocent IV and the second bore gifts and letters from Louis IX of France to Güyük Khan. Well acquainted with the Middle-East, he spoke Arabic and 'Chaldean' (thought to be either Syriac or Persian).
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Peter Abelard

Peter Abelard was a medieval French scholastic philosopher, theologian and preeminent logician. The story of his affair with and love for Héloïse has become legendary.He is often described as 'the keenest thinker and boldest theologian of the 12th Century'.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Donatello

Donato di Betto Bardi was an early Renaissance Italian artist and sculptor from Florence. He is, in part, known for his work in bas-relief, a form of shallow relief sculpture that, in Donatello's case, incorporated significant 15th century developments in perspectival illusionism.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Cimabue

Benvenuto di Giuseppe was a Florentine painter and creator of mosaics. Cimabue is generally regarded as one of the first great Italian painters to break away from the Italo-Byzantine style, although he still relied on Byzantine models.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Filippo Brunelleschi

Filippo Brunelleschi was one of the foremost architects and engineers of the Italian Renaissance. He is perhaps most famous for his studies of linear perspective and engineering the dome of the Florence Cathedral, but his accomplishments also include other architectural works, sculpture, mathematics, engineering and even ship design. His principal surviving works are to be found in Florence, Italy.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Jan Hus

Jan Hus was a Czech priest, philosopher, reformer, and master at Charles University in Prague. After John Wycliffe, the theorist of ecclesiastical Reformation, Hus is considered the first Church reformer (living prior to Luther, Calvin, and Zwingli).
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Geoffrey of Monmouth

Geoffrey of Monmouth was a cleric and one of the major figures in the development of British historiography and the popularity of tales of King Arthur. He is best known for his chronicle Historia Regum Britanniae ('History of the Kings of Britain'), which was widely popular in its day and was credited uncritically well into the 16th century, being translated into various other languages from its original Latin.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
John Wycliffe

John Wycliffe was an English Scholastic philosopher, theologian, lay preacher, translator, reformer and university teacher at Oxford in England, who was known as an early dissident in the Roman Catholic Church during the 14th century. His followers were known as Lollards, a somewhat rebellious movement, which preached anticlerical and biblically-centred reforms.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Braveheart

William Wallace was a Scottish knight and landowner who became one of the main leaders during the Wars of Scottish Independence. Along with Andrew Moray, Wallace defeated an English army at the Battle of Stirling Bridge in 1297, and was Guardian of Scotland, serving until his defeat at the Battle of Falkirk. In 1305, Wallace was captured in Robroyston near Glasgow and handed over to King Edward I of England, who had him hanged, drawn, and quartered for high treason and crimes against English civilians.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Giotto

Giotto di Bondone was an Italian painter and architect from Florence in the late Middle Ages. He is generally considered the first in a line of great artists who contributed to the Italian Renaissance. Giotto's contemporary Giovanni Villani wrote that Giotto was 'the most sovereign master of painting in his time, who drew all his figures and their postures according to nature. And he was given a salary by the Comune of Florence in virtue of his talent and excellence.'
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Arnolfo di Cambio

Arnolfo di Cambio was Nicola Pisano’s chief assistant on the marble pulpit for the Duomo in Siena (1265–1268), but he soon began to work independently on an important tomb sculpture. Around 1282 he finished the monument to Cardinal Guillaume de Braye in the church of San Domenico in Orvieto, including an enthroned Madonna for which he took as a model an ancient Roman statue of the goddess Abundantia.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
Saxo Grammaticus

Saxo Grammaticus, also known as Saxo cognomine Longus was a Danish historian, thought to have been a secular clerk or secretary to Absalon, Archbishop of Lund, foremost advisor to Valdemar I of Denmark. He is the author of the first full history of Denmark.
I could use this great man.
We don't need him.
La Divina Commedia

The Divine Comedy is an epic poem written by Dante Alighieri. It is widely considered the preeminent work of Italian literature, and is seen as one of the greatest works of world literature. The poem's imaginative and allegorical vision of the afterlife is a culmination of the medieval world-view as it had developed in the Western Church. It is divided into three parts: Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso and it helped establish the Tuscan dialect, in which it is written, as the standardized Italian language.
What a great piece of art! And it's all because of my far-sightedness!

The Scrovegni Chapel

The Scrovegni Chapel contains Giotto's Last Judgment, a fresco which covers the entire wall above the chapel's entrance. Opposite it, on the chancel arch above the altar, is an unusual scene of God in Heaven despatching an angel to Earth. The series continues through the Nativity, the Passion of Jesus, the Resurrection, and the Pentecost. The panels are noted for their emotional intensity, sculptural figures, and naturalistic space. Beneath the main scenes at dado level, Giotto used a faux architectural scheme of painted marble decorations and small recesses containing figures of the Virtues and Vices painted in grisaille.

The Canticle of the Sun

The Canticle of the Sun, also known as the Laudes Creaturarum, is a religious song composed by Saint Francis of Assisi. It was written in the Umbrian dialect of Italian but has since been translated into many languages. It is believed to be among the first works of literature, if not the first, written in the Italian language. The Canticle of the Sun in its praise of God thanks Him for such creations as 'Brother Fire' and 'Sister Water'. It is an affirmation of Francis' personal theology as he often referred to animals as brothers and sisters to Mankind, rejected material accumulation and sensual comforts in favor of 'Lady Poverty'.

The Decameron

The Decameron is a 14th-century medieval allegory by Giovanni Boccaccio, told as a frame story encompassing 100 tales by ten young people. Boccaccio probably began composing the work in 1350, and finished it in 1351 or 1353. The bawdy tales of love in The Decameron range from the erotic to the tragic. Tales of wit, practical jokes, and life lessons contribute to the mosaic. In addition to its literary import, it documents life in 14th-century Italy.

The Historia Regum Britanniae

The Historia Regum Britanniae is a pseudohistorical account of British history, written by Geoffrey of Monmouth. It chronicles the lives of the kings of the Britons in a chronological narrative spanning a time of two thousand years, beginning with the Trojans founding the British nation and continuing until the Anglo-Saxons assumed control of much of Britain around the 7th century. It is one of the central pieces of the Matter of Britain.

The Basilica di Santa Maria del Fiore

The Basilica di Santa Maria del Fiore was begun in 1296 in the Gothic style to the design of Arnolfo di Cambio and completed structurally in 1436 with the dome engineered by Filippo Brunelleschi. The exterior of the basilica is faced with polychrome marble panels in various shades of green and pink bordered by white and has an elaborate 19th century Gothic Revival façade by Emilio De Fabris. The cathedral complex, located in Piazza del Duomo, includes the Baptistery and Giotto's Campanile.

Thomism

Thomism is the philosophical school that arose as a legacy of the work and thought of Saint Thomas Aquinas, philosopher, theologian, and Doctor of the Church. In philosophy, his commentaries on Aristotle are his most lasting contribution. In theology, his Summa Theologica was one of the most influential documents in medieval theology and continues to be studied today in theology and philosophy classes.

The Speculum astronomiae

The Speculum astronomiae was written by Albertus Magnus in response to the debate concerning medieval astrology that peaked in 1277 at the University of Paris, with Bishop Stephen Tempier's issuance of a list of 219 propositions that were forbidden to be believed, or indeed even to be discussed (Bianchi, 1999). Bishop Tempier and those who thought like him were motivated by a concern that much of the Aristotelian knowledge being integrated into European universities represented a challenge to Christianity.

My daughter, [From.GetTitledFirstName], has come before me almost tearful, speaking her concerns for the fate of my throne if I should pass without a male heir. My brother, the so-called 'rightful heir,' is a fool, and would see our realm in ruin!  It is an injustice even that he would inherit first, simply for the fact that I was born a woman, when I would be by far a better ruler.  What am I to do?

My daughter, [From.GetTitledFirstName], has come to speak to me in private, delicately pointing out what I already know - that my son, my heir, is poorly-suited to the throne. But she is clearly suggesting a most shocking change, that sex be disregarded altogether for such matters, as though women were equal in every way to men.

I am fortunate that my liege runs his realm according to the law of feudal contract, permitting me a chance at the throne if he should unexpectedly pass...but there is a kind of insult to the fact that he allows women to cast themselves as contenders, as though they were as deserving of the crown as men.  What am I to do?

My vassal has come before me, quietly complaining of the insult that is accorded to men and woman both when the latter are permitted to run as contenders for the throne. The Great Famine of 1315-1317

The Great Famine of 1315–1317 (occasionally dated 1315–1322) was the first of a series of large scale crises that struck Northern Europe early in the fourteenth century. From the Pyrenees to Russia and from Scotland to Italy it caused millions of deaths over an extended number of years and marks a clear end to an earlier period of growth and prosperity during the eleventh to thirteenth centuries. Starting with bad weather in spring 1315, universal crop failures lasted through 1316 until summer harvest in 1317, Europe did not fully recover until 1325.
